title: Ticket #5283: Shared port deadlock on Windows?
description:
The test job_dagman_submit_parse fails pretty regularly on Windows when the default for USE_SHARED_PORT is changed to true. The symptom is a time-out.

The last thing the test prints is "Good. We need the dag to run<1>". The next thing that's supposed to happen is the test noticing a DAGMan failure. DAGMan properly prints out 

09/25/15 15:00:30 ERROR: node B: job ID in userlog submit event (3.0.0) doesn't
match ID reported earlier by submit command (0.0.0)!  Aborting DAG; set DAGMAN_A
BORT_ON_SCARY_SUBMIT to false if you are *sure* this shouldn't cause an abort.

but its log ends with 

09/25/15 15:00:31 attempt to connect to <128.104.103.14:46247> failed: connect errno = 10048.  Will keep trying for 10 total seconds (10 to go).

rather than 

09/25/15 13:16:54 Wrote metrics file job_dagman_submit_parse.dag.metrics.
09/25/15 13:16:54 Metrics reporting is not available on this platform.
09/25/15 13:16:54 SharedPortEndpoint: Destructor: Problem in thread shutdown notification: 0
09/25/15 13:16:54 **** condor_scheduniv_exec.1.0 (condor_DAGMAN) pid 21148 EXITING WITH STATUS 1

which would tend to indicate that the DAGMan process hung trying to contact a daemon (probably the schedd). In the schedd log, we see 

09/25/15 15:00:31 (pid:11516) DaemonCore::Wake_up_select called from an unknown thread. windows tid = 7144
... 
09/25/15 15:01:36 (pid:11516) condor_read(): timeout reading 5 bytes from collector at <128.104.103.14:46247>.
09/25/15 15:01:36 (pid:11516) IO: Failed to read packet header
09/25/15 15:01:36 (pid:11516) Failed to send RESCHEDULE to unknown daemon:

This makes me think that the shared port daemon locked up, since the collector does not record any connection attempts after 15:00:28 except for two negotiator ad updates.

While investigating why job_dagman_submit_parse fails on Windows when shared port is turned on, I took a gander at the Windows socket-passing code, and discovered that it is full of scary blocking writes to and reads from a named pipe. Naturally, since it looked like the problem I was diagnosing was caused by or had a symptom of a daemon hanging, I went to look at what the passed-to side of the conversation was doing.

The passed-to (daemon) side of the conversation creates a named pipe, and then creates a thread in SharedPortEndpoint::StartListener() that blocks in the Windows equivalent of accept(). This thread writes its process ID back to the pipe (so that the shared port daemon can duplicate the received FD into the daemon's process) and then does some magic to construct the socket. (Windows sockets aren't just FDs.) At this point, it grabs a lock, adds the new socket to the list of received sockets, and releases the lock. (As far as I know, the lock operations are all OK.)

It then schedules an immediate timer so that the main daemon core thread will handle the rest of the communication. It calls Register_Timer_TS() to do so. (Which grabs a big mutex which I haven't examined.) This function calls Register_Timer, which calls TimerManager::NewTimer. TimerManager::NewTimer calls InsertTimer, which calls DaemonCore::Wake_up_select() if the next timer has changed. (Which it probably has, given that we're registering an immediate timer.) On Windows, if Wake_up_select() is called from anything other than the main thread, it does nothing. If the daemon is just waiting around for connections, it may never pick up the phone.

On further review, there's a call to Do_Wake_up_select() in Register_Timer_TS(), inside the mutex, which should cause a write to the async pipe to occur.

2015-Sep-30 17:23:22 by tlmiller:
In test run ID 343215 I added some verbose debugging information to the shared port code. In the DAGMan log, we see 

09/30/15 15:42:34 attempt to connect to <128.104.103.11:39662> failed: connect errno = 10048.  Will keep trying for 10 total seconds (10 to go).

09/30/15 15:42:36 SharedPortClient: sent connection request to schedd at <128.104.103.11:39662> for shared port id 10820_1458_4

which does seem to make it virtually certain that the shared port daemon itself is hung.

The shared port log looks rather damning, with the following being the last four lines: 

09/30/15 15:42:34 SharedPortServer: request from SCHEDD
<128.104.103.11:39662?addrs=128.104.103.11-39662&noUDP&sock=10820_1458_4> on
<128.104.103.11:22929> to connect to 17172_b666_3. (CurPending=0 PeakPending=0)
09/30/15 15:42:34 SharedPortClient::PassSocket(): Trying to open named pipe...
09/30/15 15:42:34 SharedPortClient::PassSocket(): opened named pipe.
09/30/15 15:42:34 SharedPortClient::PassSocket(): Trying to read from pipe...

as compared to earlier exchanges: 

09/30/15 15:42:33 SharedPortServer: request from TOOL on <128.104.103.11:18403>
to connect to 10820_1458_4. (CurPending=0 PeakPending=0)
09/30/15 15:42:33 SharedPortClient::PassSocket(): Trying to open named pipe...
09/30/15 15:42:33 SharedPortClient::PassSocket(): opened named pipe.
09/30/15 15:42:33 SharedPortClient::PassSocket(): Trying to read from pipe...

09/30/15 15:42:33 SharedPortClient::PassSocket(): Duplicating socket...
09/30/15 15:42:33 SharedPortClient::PassSocket(): Writing duplicated socket to pipe...

09/30/15 15:42:33 SharedPortClient: Wrote 376 bytes to named pipe.
09/30/15 15:42:33 SharedPortClient::PassSocket(): returning TRUE...

Shared port Id 17172_b666_3 belongs to the shadow?!!?

The difference between the passing and failing shadow logs seems to be "SharedPortEndpoint: Client failed to connect: 535".

when the endpoint sees ERROR_PIPE_CONNECTED, it goes into a 100% cpu loop in the endpoint thread for a minute or two. see also #5430 and related tickets.
